description: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines, typically caused by viral or bacterial infection, leading to diarrhea and vomiting. Very common in Iraq due to water quality issues and food hygiene challenges.

treatmentProtocol.referral: If severe dehydration, bloody diarrhea, or high fever persists >48 hours

prognosis: Excellent with proper hydration. Most cases resolve in 3-7 days.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, consider cholera during outbreaks. Rotavirus vaccination recommended for children.

description: Chronic metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency. Prevalence increasing rapidly in Iraq due to lifestyle changes, obesity, and dietary factors.

lifestyle: Diet modification (reduce refined carbs, increase fiber)

prognosis: Chronic condition requiring lifelong management. Good control prevents complications.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, access to medications and monitoring may be limited. Emphasize dietary control and affordable generic medications. Ramadan fasting requires special management.

description: Persistently elevated blood pressure (≥140/90 mmHg) without identifiable cause. Very common in Iraq, often undiagnosed and undertreated.
prognosis: Excellent if well-controlled. Reduces cardiovascular risk by 30-40%.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, medication adherence is challenging due to cost. Emphasize lifestyle modifications and use affordable generic medications.

description: Chronic inflammatory airway disease causing reversible airflow obstruction. Prevalence increasing in Iraq, especially in urban areas due to air pollution and dust storms.
prognosis: Good control achievable in most patients. Some may outgrow in childhood.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, dust storms are major triggers. Inhaler availability and cost may be barriers. Teach proper inhaler technique. Consider spacer devices.

description: Acute infection of the lung parenchyma, commonly bacterial or viral. Significant cause of morbidity and mortality in Iraq, especially in children and elderly.

treatmentProtocol.followup: Chest X-ray in 6 weeks if >50 years or smoker

prognosis: Good if treated early. Mortality higher in elderly and immunocompromised.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, consider TB in non-resolving pneumonia. Antibiotic resistance is increasing. Consider local resistance patterns.

description: Chronic bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting lungs. Significant public health concern in Iraq, especially in conflict-affected areas.

intensive_phase: Rifampicin + Isoniazid + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol for 2 months

prognosis: Curable with proper treatment. Relapse risk if incomplete treatment. MDR-TB has poorer prognosis.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, DOTS program available through MOH. Free treatment. MDR-TB increasing. Ensure adherence through community support. Consider TB in any chronic cough >2 weeks.

description: Chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa, often associated with H. pylori infection. Very common in Iraq due to high H. pylori prevalence.

h_pylori_eradication: Triple therapy: PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin for 14 days
Or Quadruple therapy if resistance suspected
testing: H. pylori testing (stool antigen or breath test)

prognosis: Good with H. pylori eradication. Symptoms improve in 2-4 weeks.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, H. pylori prevalence is very high (>70%). Consider empiric treatment if testing unavailable. Clarithromycin resistance increasing - may need quadruple therapy.

description: Bacterial infection of the urinary system, most commonly bladder (cystitis). Very common in Iraq, especially in women, due to hygiene challenges and water scarcity.

treatmentProtocol.followup: Urine culture if symptoms persist or recurrent infections

prognosis: Excellent with appropriate antibiotics. Symptoms improve in 24-48 hours.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, antibiotic resistance is increasing. Consider local resistance patterns. Recurrent UTIs common due to water scarcity. Emphasize hydration.

description: Degenerative joint disease characterized by cartilage breakdown and joint pain. Common in Iraq, especially in elderly and those with obesity or previous joint injuries.

surgical: Joint replacement if severe and refractory

prognosis: Progressive condition. Symptoms can be managed but not cured. Joint replacement very effective for severe cases.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, access to joint replacement surgery limited. Emphasize weight loss and physical therapy. NSAIDs widely used but monitor for GI side effects.

description: Excessive body fat accumulation (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) that presents health risks. Rapidly increasing in Iraq due to dietary changes, sedentary lifestyle, and urbanization.

surgical: Bariatric surgery if BMI >40 or >35 with comorbidities

prognosis: Weight loss improves health outcomes. Requires long-term lifestyle changes. High relapse rate.
specialConsiderations: In Iraq, cultural factors promote high-calorie foods and large portions. Address cultural beliefs. Bariatric surgery limited availability. Focus on dietary modification and physical activity.
